A few points:
1. It is NOT correct to claim that Europeans enslaved Africans taken to the Americas. Those Africans were made slaves IN Africa, enslavement is the process of making someone a slave which Europeans had generally avoided, in Europe since the High Middle Ages and against non-Christians by the Renaissance.
2. Claiming that the Integration of the Americas into the Spanish Empire is "genocide" is not accurate - Disease was not intentionally used against Native populations and the vast majority of the violence committed in the 16th century was perpetrated by Natives against Natives under European influence.
3. Claiming that it's a good thing that Europeans began to question the naturalness of their way of life implies that conclusion to be incorrect when such a claim could not be substantiated either way.

Not sure how useful this information is considering how organised in advanced you guys are but as a side note for talking about the transfer/transplantation of plants around the world its interesting to talk about the connections and influence Kew Botanical Gardens made in the C18th and C19th. It was Kew who sent Darwin on his expedition to South America for example, but their connections with other botanical institutes around the world and their thirst for usable knowledge of plants arguably was a significant if not dominant force in the British colonial expansion at this time. Consequently some of its colonial activities have had significant detrimental consequences with hindsight but i think overall its worthy of inclusion in a series like this

It was not an exchange, it was a wholesale assault and pillaging of non-European material and cultural resources; one which continues today.

"European states had been too small and poor to support large navies" Is, while argueably true within the context of western Europe in the middle ages, quite misleading. Decidedly European states like the Romans, Byzantines, Franks etc. were very much rich enough to support large navies, it just wasn't a priority, as they had other means of expansion.
I also feel there's missing some discussion of the material conditions of Europe vs. China/East & South Asia. China was simply too rich to have any reason to go looking for more land, where Europe, which had recently been cut off from the valuable trade-routes of the Middle East by the rise of islamic empires like the Ottomans in Anatolia and Mamluks in Egypt, was suddenly experiencing a limitation in their access to material wealth, which lead them to searching for other routes to the riches of the east.

This may seem like pointless nitpicking, but I think it's actually pretty important to understanding history. European exploration had very little to do with ideas, and everything to do with the material conditions of Europe at the time. This is always the case; History is driven by changing material conditions and the societal dynamics that causes, not merely by ideas. Ideas are a result of the material conditions of the society in which they are born, not the other way around.

Really interesting video. Only gripe is at 5:34, Scotland has never been part of England. The Act of Union was signed in the year of Carl Linnaeus' birth (1707), and even then that was to form the United Kingdom. That's the only complaint, keep up the good work

When I was in high school (before political correctness was invented) we were taught that the Age of Exploration was caused by the fall of the Byzantine Empire in 1453 and the resulting loss of the land route from Europe to the Far East.  Europe needed spices (I think SciShow taught us it was NOT to kill the taste of rotten food [as I was also taught] but to kill the actual bacteria in rotten food -- but they needed them either way) and had to find another way to get them.  Columbus didn't think the Americas were there -- and he also somehow got the circumference of the earth wrong (even though that had been known since classical times) and thought Asia would be a shorter trip than it would be if the Americas were NOT there -- and was trying to find the Spice Islands -- or the Indies, hence the West Indies which he incorrectly thought were the East Indies, which at the time were the ONLY Indies.  Is this just flat out WRONG, or is it politically incorrect to blame all that colonizing and exploitation (even indirectly) on the Ottomans taking Constantinople?
Exploration.

A missed opportunity to talk about the scientific exchange between Muslims and Christians in the Iberian peninsula that allowed for the age of exploration to start in the first place! Without the Islamic presence in Iberia and the navigational knowledge they left there, there would be no caravels and no astrolabe, and thus Portugal and Spain probably wouldn't have undertaken their voyages. It's a pity that you didn't mention this oft overlooked historical chain of events, and instead talked about the same old tired narrative of the Columbian exchange yet again...

No, they have found malaria in the preserved city of Pompeii. Like really proved it with skeletons of children who had congenital syphilis. It shows very clearly in both the bone matrix and leaves specific marks on the teeth. It is harder to definitively prove in adults who catch it, but congenital syphilis can only be contracted from the mother at a specific time in pregnancy if she is still infectious. This evidence has been around for years- including a monastery in Europe in the decade before Columbus went off (though those bones are of adults and it is harder to categorically say 'IT MUST BE SYPHILIS' because other things can leave similar marks, but it is more likely to have been syphilis than everyone else had a cocktail of syphilis-like diseases). It occurs to me that despite the growing evidence (Mary BEARD.), there is a cultural bias towards thinking of syphilis as a scientific puzzle, which can be solved, rather than some ingrained truth like how Columbus wasn't a murderer and cruel guy who decimated the Taino people. I would super like it if you could look at some research and amend the syphilis phrasing, because until people who have a voice (like you do) in culture and society stand up and say 'this cultural bias is hurting actual attempts to prove the origin of syphilis' there is still going to be a huge stigma for anyone saying 'hold on, there is contradicting evidence that Columbus introduced syphilis to Europe'.
